content.headline: Cedar Creek Fire: Severe burn patterns detected across 81,000 acres
content.summary: Analysis of MTBS satellite imagery reveals 63.6% of the 127,341-acre fire perimeter experienced high-severity burn. The Hills Creek drainage (SW-1) and central fire origin (CORE-1) show complete stand replacement with significant erosion risk.
details: High severity (>75% mortality): 81,041 acres concentrated in SW and central sectors
Moderate severity (25-75% mortality): 37,900 acres in NE quadrant, natural regeneration potential
Low severity (<25% mortality): 8,400 acres near Timpanogas Lake, minimal intervention needed

chain.evidence: dNBR values range from 0.22 (low) to 0.81 (high) across 8 sectors

chain.thought: Identifying priority areas based on severity and slope interaction
chain.evidence: SW-1 and CORE-1 combine high severity (dNBR >0.7) with steep slopes (>35%)

content.headline: Critical trail infrastructure damage: 3 bridges destroyed, $447K in repairs needed
content.summary: Assessment of 5 trails totaling 40.3 miles reveals 16 damage points including 3 complete bridge failures. Hills Creek Trail requires $238K alone due to primary bridge loss and debris flow burial. Waldo Lake Trail is priority 1 for visitor access restoration.
details: Bridge failures: Waldo Lake (40ft timber), Bobby Lake (puncheon), Hills Creek (primary crossing)
Debris flows: 2 major, 1 moderate - trail reroute assessment needed at Waldo MP 4.7
Hazard trees: 175+ identified across all trails, clearing required before reopening
Timeline: 153 crew-days needed for full restoration

chain.evidence: Hills Creek Trail traverses SW-1 (highest severity); Waldo Lake Trail crosses NW-1 and NW-2

chain.thought: Prioritizing based on visitor use patterns and access criticality
chain.evidence: Waldo Lake Trail: 15,000 annual visitors; Hills Creek: salvage access route

content.headline: Salvage opportunity: $13.9M in recoverable timber across 8,500 acres
content.summary: Cruise data from 6 representative plots indicates 230,350 MBF of salvageable timber. Plot 52-FOXTROT in SW-1 sector contains premium large-diameter Douglas-fir with immediate extraction priority. Blue stain degradation timeline requires action within 18 months.
details: Highest priority: Plot 52-FOXTROT - $3,225/acre salvage value, 1S grade Douglas-fir to 36.8" DBH
High priority: Plots 47-ALPHA and 47-BRAVO in SW-1 - combined 75 MBF/acre average
Access constraint: Hills Creek bridge repair prerequisite for SW-1 harvest operations
Species mix: 45% Douglas-fir, 22% Lodgepole Pine, 12% Western Redcedar

chain.thought: Analyzing plot data for salvage value and extraction feasibility
chain.evidence: 6 plots sampled using BAF 20; extrapolated to 8,500 salvageable acres based on severity mapping

chain.thought: Prioritizing by timber value, access, and time sensitivity
chain.evidence: Large-diameter Douglas-fir degrades fastest; SW-1 has best road access post-repair

content.headline: Salvage EA pathway identified: Emergency situation determination recommended
content.summary: Analysis of FSM 2520 and 36 CFR 220.6 indicates Cedar Creek salvage qualifies for emergency situation categorical exclusion. Given the $13.9M timber value and 18-month degradation window, recommend expedited EA over standard EIS timeline. Key considerations: spotted owl habitat, Waldo Lake viewshed, and cultural resource surveys.
details: Recommended pathway: Emergency Situation CE under 36 CFR 220.6(e)(6) for initial units
Required surveys: Level III cultural resource survey for SW-1 ground disturbance areas
Spotted owl: No known activity centers within 0.25 miles of priority harvest units
Waldo Lake Scenic Area: Buffer required for NW-1 and NW-2 viewshed protection

chain.thought: Evaluating NEPA pathway options for post-fire salvage
chain.evidence: FSM 2520.4 establishes emergency situation criteria; Cedar Creek meets deteriorating resource condition threshold

chain.thought: Identifying categorical exclusion applicability
chain.evidence: 36 CFR 220.6(e)(6) permits salvage up to 250 acres without extraordinary circumstances

chain.thought: Assessing extraordinary circumstances
chain.evidence: No designated wilderness, wild & scenic rivers, or inventoried roadless areas in SW-1 harvest units

chain.thought: Recommending hybrid approach for scale
chain.evidence: CE for initial 250-acre priority units; EA for remaining 8,250 acres with 6-month parallel timeline

content.headline: Cedar Creek Recovery Synthesis: Integrated action plan ready for review
content.summary: Cross-agent analysis complete. The cascade reveals a critical dependency: Hills Creek bridge repair ($120K) unlocks $13.9M in salvage value and enables trail network restoration. Recommended prioritization: 1) Emergency bridge repair, 2) Salvage CE for initial 250 acres, 3) Parallel EA for full project, 4) Trail restoration concurrent with salvage access.
details: Total recovery investment: $447K trails + $2.1M salvage operations = $2.55M
Projected return: $13.9M gross timber value - 27:1 ROI on trail investment
Timeline critical path: 18-month salvage window begins deteriorating Q2 2024
Risk factors: Spotted owl breeding season (Feb-Jul) may delay NW sector access

cross_agent_insights.implication: HC-001 bridge is highest-leverage investment for full recovery
High-severity areas (SW-1, CORE-1) contain premium timber; prioritize over moderate zones
CE for initial units can begin while EA processes for full project
